{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11190,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Centaurium erythraea prefers well-drained soil and requires moderate watering. Ensure the soil is kept moist, especially during dry periods, but avoid waterlogging as this can harm the plant. It is important to let the soil surface dry out slightly between waterings. During the growing season, typically in spring and summer, increase the frequency of watering. However, reduce watering in autumn and winter when the plant enters a period of dormancy. Using rainwater or distilled water at room temperature is advisable, as this plant can be sensitive to tap water chemicals."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Centaurium erythraea thrives in full sun to partial shade. It prefers bright, direct sunlight for optimal growth and flowering. Ideally, the plant should receive at least 6 hours of sunlight per day when planted outdoors. In areas with hot summer climates, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch. If grown indoors, place the plant near a south or west-facing window to ensure it receives ample light. Maintaining the right balance of sunlight helps promote robust growth, vibrant flowers, and can improve the plant's overall health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Centaurium erythraea is generally minimal, but it can benefit from deadheading spent flowers to encourage further blooming and improve overall aesthetics. This process involves cutting off the flower heads once they start to wilt and die. It is best done with clean, sharp scissors or pruners to avoid damaging the plant. Additionally, at the end of the growing season, the plant can be cut back to the ground to prepare it for winter. This helps maintain a tidy appearance and can stimulate healthier growth in the following season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Common centaury","description":"Centaurium erythraea is a species of flowering plant in the gentian family known by the common names common centaury and European centaury.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","North Africa","Western Asia"],"other_name":["Common centaury"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Centaurium erythraea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10589,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Woodwardia fimbriata, commonly known as the giant chain fern, prefers consistently moist soil. It is important to water it regularly to ensure the soil remains damp but not waterlogged. During the growing season, it might require more frequent watering, especially if grown in containers. Reduce watering slightly in the winter months to prevent root rot. Avoid letting the soil dry out completely between waterings, as this can cause stress to the plant. Maintaining humidity by misting or placing a humidity tray beneath the plant can also benefit its growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Giant chain ferns thrive in partial to full shade, making them ideal for woodland gardens or shaded areas of your landscape. Direct sunlight, especially intense afternoon sun, can scorch the fronds, leading to browning and damage. If planted in an area with some sun exposure, morning light is preferable as it is less intense. In dense shade, make sure there is enough indirect light to support healthy growth. If growing indoors, place near a north or east-facing window to mimic its natural forest habitat."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Woodwardia fimbriata involves removing old or damaged fronds to encourage healthy growth and maintain its appearance. This can be done in early spring before new growth begins, or as needed throughout the growing season. Use sharp, clean pruning shears to trim the fronds at their base, ensuring you do not damage new growth. Regularly check for any dead or discolored foliage and remove it promptly. Pruning also helps improve air circulation around the plant, reducing the potential for fungal diseases."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"giant chain fern","description":"Woodwardia fimbriata, known by the common name giant chain fern, is a fern species in the family Blechnaceae, in the eupolypods II clade of the order Polypodiales, in the class Polypodiopsida. It is native to western North America from British Columbia through California, including the Sierra Nevada, into Baja California.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["giant chain fern"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spores"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Woodwardia fimbriata"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained","Humus-rich"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11587,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Schismus barbatus is a drought-tolerant grass that requires minimal watering. It thrives best in dry, well-drained soils, and over-watering can lead to root rot. During its active growing season in spring, a light watering once every two weeks should suffice, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings. In periods of dormancy or outside the growing season, reduce watering significantly, providing moisture only during prolonged dry spells to maintain health without encouraging excessive growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Schismus barbatus prefers full sun to thrive but can also tolerate partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight every day to support its growth and flowering. In regions with intense summer heat, providing some afternoon shade can prevent stress. If grown in too much shade, growth may become weak and spindly with reduced flowering. Ensuring the plant is in a location with ample sunlight will help it develop its characteristic dense, low mounding form and vibrant appearance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Schismus barbatus is generally not necessary, as it is a low-growing grass that maintains a naturally tidy form. However, if you wish to tidy up the plant or remove dead material, prune in late winter to early spring before new growth begins. Use sharp scissors or a small pruning shears to cut back any spent flowering stems and remove any brown or dead foliage to encourage healthy, new growth and prevent disease. Regularly removing dead sections can also help improve air circulation around the base of the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"common Mediterranean grass","description":"Schismus barbatus is a species of grass known as common Mediterranean grass and kelch-grass. It is native to Eurasia, and it is also known as an introduced species in the southwestern United States. It grows in many habitats, including disturbed areas. It is an annual grass growing in small clumps. The stems grow up to 27 centimeters long and are lined with threadlike leaves. The short inflorescence bears spikelets under a centimeter long.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North Africa","Western Asia","Southern Europe"],"other_name":["common Mediterranean grass"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Schismus barbatus"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Afternoon"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10290,"attracts":["Pollinators","Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Carpobrotus edulis, also known as the ice plant, is drought-tolerant and requires minimal watering. During the growing season, water the plant deeply once every two weeks or so, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings. Avoid over-watering, as this can lead to root rot. During the winter months, reduce watering significantly, as the plant goes dormant and needs very little moisture. In humid or rainy climates, natural rainfall is often sufficient to meet its needs, so additional watering is generally unnecessary."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Carpobrotus edulis thrives in full sun and requires at least six hours of direct sunlight daily to flourish. It does best in bright, sunny locations and can tolerate the heat of full afternoon sun. This makes it an ideal choice for xeriscaping and coastal gardens where sunlight is abundant. While it can survive in partial shade, its growth may become leggy and flowers less frequent without adequate sun. Ensure it's planted in a spot where it won't be overshadowed by taller plants or structures to maintain its vibrant growth and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Regular pruning is important for Carpobrotus edulis to prevent it from growing too aggressively and to maintain its shape. Prune the plant in the spring or early fall by cutting back leggy and overgrown stems to encourage bushier growth. Remove any dead or diseased foliage, which helps improve air circulation and overall plant health. Be careful not to cut the plant back too severely, as the ice plant relies on its leaves for photosynthesis. Pruning also helps control the spread of Carpobrotus edulis, as it can become invasive in some regions."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"sea fig","description":"Carpobrotus edulis is a ground-creeping plant with succulent leaves in the genus Carpobrotus, native to South Africa. It is also known as Hottentot-fig, ice plant, highway ice plant or pigface and in South Africa as the sour fig (suurvy).","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":"Spring","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["sea fig"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Carpobrotus edulis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11287,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Croton capitatus, commonly known as the Woolly Croton, prefers moderately moist soil but is relatively drought-tolerant once established. Water this plant regularly during the growing season, allowing the soil to dry out slightly between waterings. Reduce watering in the winter months when the plant is not actively growing. Be cautious not to overwater, as Croton capitatus does not tolerate waterlogged conditions, which can lead to root rot. A good practice is to check the soil’s top inch for dryness before deciding to water again, ensuring the plant receives just the right amount of moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Croton capitatus thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth and foliage coloration, provide it with at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight each day. In extremely hot climates, some afternoon shade can protect the plant from leaf scorch. Indoors, place the plant near a bright, south-facing window where it receives ample indirect light if direct sunlight isn’t possible. However, without enough sunlight, Croton capitatus can become leggy and lose its vibrant foliage, so ensure it receives the correct light levels for a healthy appearance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Croton capitatus helps maintain its shape and promotes healthy growth. It's best done during the growing season in spring or early summer. Remove any dead or damaged branches, and trim back any overly long stems to encourage bushier growth. Make clean cuts just above a leaf node or lateral branch using sharp, sterilized pruning shears. Avoid heavy pruning, as this can stress the plant. In addition, regularly remove any lower or older leaves to improve air circulation and prevent disease, helping to keep the plant vigorous and attractive."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"woolly croton","description":"Croton capitatus, known as the hogwort or woolly croton or goatweed, is an annual plant with erect, branched stems, densely covered with light brown, wooly hairs that give it a whitish appearance. It grows in dry, open areas, especially sandy and rocky soils. It is distributed across the southern United States, and elsewhere.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["woolly croton"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Croton capitatus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It's important to water this plant regularly to maintain soil moisture, especially during dry spells. However, ensure good drainage to prevent root rot. During the growing season, you may need to water more frequently, whereas in colder months, let the topsoil dry out slightly between watering sessions. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11692,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Verbascum thapsus, commonly known as common mullein, requires minimal watering once established, as it is drought-tolerant. In its first growing season, water the plant regularly to help establish the roots, ensuring the soil remains slightly moist but not waterlogged. After establishment, typically by its second year, reduce watering frequency. Water during prolonged dry spells or when the soil is extremely dry. Ensure the soil has good drainage to prevent root rot. Avoid overwatering, as excessive moisture can lead to plant stress, diseases, or root damage."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Verbascum thapsus thrives in full sun, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily. It can tolerate partial shade but may not grow as robustly or bloom as profusely. Full sun conditions promote the healthiest plants, with vibrant leaves and copious, upright flower spikes. Plant it in a location that receives plenty of light throughout the day, avoiding overly shaded areas which could lead to leggy growth and reduced flowering. Adequate sunlight also helps reduce disease risk by keeping foliage dry and well-ventilated."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Verbascum thapsus is generally minimal. To maintain appearance and encourage new growth, remove spent flower stalks after blooming. This also helps to prevent excessive self-seeding, as common mullein can spread rapidly if left unchecked. Deadheading spent flowers can encourage a second bloom period. In late fall or early spring, cut back any dead or damaged foliage to make way for new growth. Also, prune any branches that touch the ground, as they can take root and lead to an unmanageable mess. However, avoid over-watering as the plant is prone to root rot in excessively moist soil. Watering once a week is typically sufficient, adjusting based on rainfall and soil moisture. Ensure proper drainage to prevent waterlogging, which can hinder the plant’s growth. During dormant periods, such as winter, reduce watering frequency. Keeping the soil evenly moist but not soggy will support optimal growth conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sorghum halepense thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight daily to achieve optimal growth. It can adapt to partial shade but may not develop as robustly as it would in full sun. Ensure the planting location receives ample direct light, especially during the peak growing season, to support its strong, rapid growth habits. In shaded conditions, the plant might grow taller as it reaches for light but could become weaker. Adequate sunlight also aids in flowering and seed production, which are essential for the plant's reproductive cycle and biomass development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Sorghum halepense involves removing dead or damaged stems to promote new growth and maintain plant health. It's best to prune during its dormant season, typically in late fall or early winter, to minimize stress. Use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts near the base of the stalk for effective pruning. Control the spread by trimming back any overly aggressive growth throughout the growing season. Regular maintenance helps prevent this invasive species from overtaking garden spaces and promotes better air circulation. Dispose of cuttings carefully to avoid unintended propagation through dropped seeds or rhizomes."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Johnson grass","description":"Johnson grass or Johnsongrass, Sorghum halepense, is a plant in the grass family, Poaceae, native to the Mediterranean region, but grows throughout Europe and the Middle East. If growing in sunnier locations, ensure the plant is watered frequently and that the soil stays consistently moist to prevent leaf scorch or stress."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Cornus florida should be done during the dormant season in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. Focus on removing dead, diseased, or crossing branches to maintain a healthy structure. Also, thin out the crown to improve air circulation and enhance its natural shape. Avoid heavy pruning as it may lead to stress on the plant. After flowering, light pruning can be done to shape the plant and remove spent blooms. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent the spread of pathogens."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"flowering dogwood","description":"Cornus florida, the flowering dogwood, is a species of flowering plant in the family Cornaceae native to eastern North America and northern Mexico. This helps the plant develop a strong root system and prevents the potential for root rot. During particularly hot or dry spells, you may need to increase the frequency to twice a week. Morning watering is ideal to minimize evaporation and reduce the risk of mold or mildew on the leaves."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Tomato plants, or Solanum lycopersicum, require full sun to produce healthy fruit. They thrive best when they receive at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day. Adequate sunlight helps to foster strong growth and robust fruiting. In regions with extremely hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent the plants from becoming stressed from excessive heat. Setting up your tomato plants in a spot with proper southern or southwestern exposure is ideal to ensure they absorb sufficient sunlight to produce an abundant, healthy crop."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is important for Solanum lycopersicum to promote healthy growth and increase fruit yield. Begin by removing any suckers, which are the small shoots that emerge from where the leaf stem meets the main stem. These suckers draw energy away from fruit production, so regular removal is advised. Also, trim away any yellowing or diseased leaves to enhance air circulation and reduce the risk of disease. Pruning is best done early in the morning or late in the evening to avoid causing stress to the plant during the hottest parts of the day."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"tomato","description":"The tomato (see pronunciation) is the edible, often red, fruit of the plant Solanum lycopersicum, commonly known as a tomato plant. The plant belongs to the nightshade family, Solanaceae. The species originated in western South America. The Nahuatl (Aztec language) word tomatl gave rise to the Spanish word \"tomate\", from which the English word tomato derived. Its use as a cultivated food may have originated with the indigenous peoples of Peru and Ecuador. The Spanish discovered...","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South America"],"other_name":["tomato"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Nematodes","Aphids","Whiteflies","Blossom end rot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Solanum lycopersicum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11995,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Prunus laurocerasus, commonly known as cherry laurel, prefers consistently moist but well-drained soil. It is important not to let the soil completely dry out, especially during warm weather when the plant may require more frequent watering. Conversely, overwatering and waterlogged conditions should be avoided as these can lead to root rot. A good practice is to check the top few inches of soil; if they feel dry to the touch, it is time to water. Mulching around the base can help retain moisture and reduce the need for frequent watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Prunus laurocerasus can adapt to a wide range of light conditions, though it thrives best in partial to full shade. While it can tolerate full sun, especially in cooler climates, too much direct sunlight, particularly in hot regions, can scorch the leaves. For optimal growth, providing a setting with morning sunlight and afternoon shade can help the plant maintain its vibrant foliage without suffering from leaf burn. In shaded locations, it will grow more slowly but will still contribute significantly to the garden's greenery."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Regular pruning is essential for maintaining the shape and health of Prunus laurocerasus. It is best done in late spring or early summer after flowering. You can trim back any overgrown or unwanted branches to maintain the desired size and shape. It's also important to remove any dead or diseased wood as soon as it is noticed, which helps prevent the spread of disease. Use clean, sharp shears to make cuts at a slight angle just above a leaf node or bud to encourage healthy regrowth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Cherry laurel","description":"Prunus laurocerasus, also known as cherry laurel, common laurel and sometimes English laurel in North America, is an evergreen species of cherry (Prunus), native to regions bordering the Black Sea in southwestern Asia and southeastern Europe, from Albania and Bulgaria east through Turkey to the Caucasus Mountains and northern Iran.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia Minor"],"other_name":["Cherry laurel"],"pest_susceptibility":["Leaf spot","Shot hole disease","Canker"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Prunus laurocerasus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12090,"attracts":["Insects"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Utricularia cornuta, also known as horned bladderwort, is a carnivorous plant that thrives in wet, boggy conditions. It’s important to keep the substrate consistently moist but not waterlogged. Use distilled or rainwater as this plant is sensitive to the minerals and chemicals often found in tap water. The water level should be just enough to keep the substrate damp, emulating its natural wetland habitat. It's best to use a tray method, keeping about 1-2 inches of water in a tray under the pot, allowing the plant to absorb moisture as needed."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Utricularia cornuta prefers bright, indirect sunlight to replicate the conditions of its natural habitat. Direct sunlight could potentially harm the plant, causing scorched leaves, so it’s best to place it where it receives filtered light, such as near an east or west-facing window. If the sunlight is too intense, consider using a sheer curtain to diffuse the light. If natural light is insufficient, especially during winter months, supplementing with fluorescent grow lights can help maintain adequate light levels to support healthy growth. Aim for about 12-14 hours of light daily."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Utricularia cornuta is generally straightforward and mostly involves removing dead or decaying foliage to promote healthy growth and maintain the plant's aesthetic. As a small, delicate plant, manual handling should be gentle to avoid damage. Prune off spent flower stalks to encourage potential re-blooming and to direct energy back into the plant. Be sure to use sterilized scissors or shears to prevent the introduction of bacteria or pests. Regular inspections and minimal, routine maintenance will aid in preventing disease spread and maintaining plant vitality."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Horned Bladderwort","description":"Utricularia cornuta, the horned bladderwort, is a small to medium-sized, probably perennial carnivorous plant that belongs to the genus Utricularia. It grows as a terrestrial or subaquatic plant in marshes, swamps, and pools in shallow waters, mostly at lower altitudes. It was originally described and published by André Michaux in 1803.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Horned Bladderwort"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Utricularia cornuta"],"soil":["Acidic","Wet","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11095,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lamium purpureum, or Red Dead Nettle, thrives in moist but well-draining soil. It doesn't require much water once established but should be watered during prolonged dry spells to keep the soil slightly moist. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's important to allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. During the spring and fall, when growth is active, you might need to water more frequently. In contrast, reduce watering significantly in the hotter months when the plant is not actively growing or if it becomes dormant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lamium purpureum can adapt to different light conditions but performs best in partial shade to full shade. It’s ideal for areas with dappled sunlight, under trees, or in garden spots that receive morning sun with afternoon shade. Too much direct sunlight, especially in hotter climates, can scorch the leaves and necessitate more frequent watering to prevent wilting. Conversely, in cooler climates, it might tolerate more sun. Observing the plant's response to its light conditions will guide any necessary adjustments to its location."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lamium purpureum involves removing dead or decayed leaves to encourage new growth and maintain a tidy appearance. It's best to perform pruning in the late spring or early summer after it has finished flowering. Snipping spent flower heads can also promote more blooms. Regularly managing the plant's spread is crucial as it can be invasive. Using clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears, trims back any overgrown stems to control its growth. Periodically thinning out the plant can enhance air circulation and prevent fungal diseases."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"red deadnettle","description":"Lamium purpureum, known as red dead-nettle, purple dead-nettle, red henbit, purple archangel, or velikdenche, is a herbaceous flowering plant native to Europe and Asia.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Spring","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["red deadnettle"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Lamium purpureum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Once matured, water sparingly, approximately once every two weeks or when the soil is completely dry, mimicking its natural arid environment."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Acmispon brachycarpus thrives in full sunlight conditions, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily. Cut back any dead, damaged, or crossing branches using sharp and clean pruning shears. Avoid heavy pruning, as it can stress the plant. Water the plant deeply whenever the top inch of soil feels dry. Be cautious of overwatering, though, as the plant can still suffer from root rot if it stands in waterlogged soil for extended periods. If planted in full shade, the plant might become leggy and produce fewer blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cornus foemina is generally done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. To maintain a healthy structure and encourage lush growth, remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches. Pruning also helps in improving air circulation and light penetration within the bush, which can lead to healthier foliage and more prolific blooming. Avoid excessive pruning as this can stress the plant and reduce its natural beauty; simply shape it to your desired form or to fit the space it inhabits."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Stiff Dogwood","description":"Cornus foemina is a species of flowering plant in the Cornaceae known by the common names stiff dogwood and swamp dogwood. Ensure that the plant receives at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight to maintain robust health and seed production."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Generally, Vulpia microstachys does not require much pruning. During its initial establishment phase, it requires regular watering to help develop a strong root system; however, once established, it thrives on infrequent watering. Generally, it should be watered every two to three weeks, or only when the top 2 inches of the soil have dried out completely. Overwatering can lead to root rot and negatively affect the health of the plant, so it's vital to allow the soil to dry thoroughly between watering sessions to mimic its natural desert environment and keep it thriving."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Encelia farinosa thrives best in full sunlight, which simulates its native desert habitat conditions. If grown in partial shade, you might notice reduced blooming and a less vigorous plant. In regions with extremely high temperatures, providing a little afternoon shade can help protect the plant from intense heat. However, in general, this plant is adapted to hot, sunny climates and flourishes with ample sunlight."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Encelia farinosa should be done minimally, usually after its blooming period in the spring. When pruning, focus on removing stems at the base rather than cutting back branches mid-way. Ensure that the soil is well-drained to prevent waterlogging, which can harm the plant's root system. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot and other diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Avena barbata prefers full sunlight to thrive but can tolerate partial shade. For optimal growth, plant it in a location where it will receive at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily. In partially shaded areas, it may still grow, but the plant might not reach its full potential or produce as many seed heads. However, to maintain its appearance and health, you can remove dead or damaged blades as needed. This can be done by cutting the old foliage close to the ground once it turns brown, usually in late fall or early winter, to encourage new growth in the spring. Avoid cutting the plant too early or aggressively, as it might not recover well. Regularly clearing out dead leaves can also help prevent diseases and improve air circulation."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"slender wild oat","description":"Avena barbata is a species of wild oat known by the common name slender wild oat. Its diploid ancestors are A. hirtula Lag. and A. wiestii Steud (2n=2x=14), which are considered Mediterranean and desert ecotypes, respectively, comprising a single species. A wiestii and A. hirtula are widespread in the Mediterranean Basin, growing in mixed stands with A. barbata, though they are difficult to tell apart.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mediterranean Region"],"other_name":["slender wild oat"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Avena barbata"],"soil":["Loamy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12091,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Gaultheria procumbens, commonly known as wintergreen, prefers consistently moist soil, especially in the growing season. However, be cautious not to overwater, as standing water or overly wet soil can cause root rot. In late autumn and winter, reduce the frequency of watering, allowing the top layer of soil to dry out between waterings while maintaining enough moisture to support the plant's root system. Good drainage is crucial, so ensure the planting area allows excess water to escape."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Gaultheria procumbens thrives best in partial to full shade. It is well-suited for woodland gardens or areas with filtered sunlight. In natural habitats, wintergreen often grows under forest canopies, so try to mimic this environment in your garden. While it can tolerate some direct sunlight, too much exposure, particularly in hot afternoon sun, can scorch leaves and cause stress. In cooler climates, it may withstand more sun. If you notice the leaves browning or curling, it could be a sign of sun stress, so consider relocating the plant to a more shaded spot if necessary."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Gaultheria procumbens is relatively straightforward and is primarily done to maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. Prune in early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead or damaged branches with clean, sharp pruning shears. If your wintergreen becomes leggy or sparse, trim back overgrown stems to promote denser growth. Avoid heavy pruning; simply take off a few inches to shape the plant as desired. Regularly removing spent flowers and old foliage can improve appearance and health. Always sterilize your pruning tools before and after use to prevent disease spread."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Eastern Teaberry","description":"Gaultheria procumbens, also called the eastern teaberry, the checkerberry, the boxberry, or the American wintergreen, is a species of Gaultheria native to northeastern North America from Newfoundland west to southeastern Manitoba, and south to Alabama. It is a member of the Ericaceae (heath family).","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Eastern Teaberry"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Gaultheria procumbens"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

However, as a general guideline, ensuring that the host plants receive sufficient sunlight according to their species' needs will help support Orobanche gracilis indirectly."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Orobanche gracilis is generally not required, as it is a parasitic plant that completes its life cycle by extracting nutrients from a host plant. However, if control is desired due to the impact on the host, manually removing the broomrape before it flowers can help prevent seed spread. This action may help manage its population and reduce further impact on host plants, although it will not eradicate it entirely due to the robust underground seed bank and parasitic nature."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Slender Broomrape","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Pale yellow to brownish","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Slender Broomrape"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Orobanche gracilis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Dry"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

When planting, choose a spot that receives ample sunlight throughout the day to ensure robust health and an abundant display of blooms. If grown indoors, place it near a south or west-facing window to maximize light exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Acmispon americanus is not typically required, but it can help maintain a tidy appearance and encourage bushier growth. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11892,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Saururus cernuus, commonly known as lizard's tail, prefers consistently moist to wet soil conditions, as it is native to swamps and wetlands. To mimic its natural habitat, ensure that the soil is always damp but not waterlogged. Water regularly to maintain soil moisture, especially during the growing season (spring and summer), but reduce watering slightly during the dormant period in winter. If grown in a container, check that the pot has adequate drainage to prevent water stagnation. Standing in shallow water is acceptable, making it perfect for water gardens or boggy areas."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Saururus cernuus thrives best in full sun to partial shade conditions, which reflects its natural habitat along the edges of ponds and wetlands. While it tolerates full sun, in very hot climates, partial shade can prevent leaf burn and stress. In cooler climates, providing more sunlight encourages robust growth and flowering. If the plant is receiving too much direct sunlight, its leaves might show signs of scorching, indicating the need for a bit more shade. An ideal location features filtered light or morning sun followed by afternoon shade. "},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Saururus cernuus is generally minimal but can help maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. Prune back any dead or damaged stems in late fall or early spring before new growth starts. Cutting the plant back to ground level in late autumn can help rejuvenate it for the next growing season. This plant spreads quickly through rhizomes, so you may need to cut back or thin out the plant to control its spread in your garden. Always use clean, sharp pruning tools to make clean cuts and reduce the risk of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"lizard's tail","description":"Saururus cernuus (lizard's tail, water-dragon, swamp root) is a medicinal and ornamental plant native to eastern North America. It grows in wet areas or shallow water, and can be up to about a meter tall. The native range covers much of the eastern United States, as far west as eastern Texas and Kansas, south to Florida, and north to Michigan and New York state, slightly into Ontario.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Eastern North America"],"other_name":["lizard's tail"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Saururus cernuus"],"soil":["Wet","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Once mature, gorse plants usually rely on rainfall and should not need additional watering unless there are prolonged dry spells. In such cases, watering once every two to three weeks should suffice to maintain healthy growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ulex europaeus thrives in full sunlight and requires at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sun per day. It is well-suited for planting in open areas where it can receive ample sunlight. In conditions where sunlight is limited, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer flowers. Therefore, it is best to avoid planting in shaded or partially-shaded areas. Providing Ulex europaeus with the required sunlight not only enhances its growth but also ensures vibrant flowering, which is one of its distinctive characteristics."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ulex europaeus is essential to maintain its shape and promote healthy growth. It usually involves cutting back the plant after it has finished flowering, which helps prevent it from becoming too woody. Trim back any dead or unruly branches to encourage dense, bushy growth. Light trimming throughout the growing season can also help maintain its desired form."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"gorse","description":"Ulex europaeus (gorse, common gorse, furze or whin) is a species of flowering plant in the family Fabaceae, native to portions of Europe from the northern United Kingdom south to Portugal, and from the western Republic of Ireland east to Galicja in Poland and Ukraine.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":"Spring","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["gorse"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Ulex europaeus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10988,"attracts":["Bees","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Acacia baileyana, commonly known as Cootamundra wattle, is drought tolerant once established and requires minimal watering. During the first year after planting, water the tree regularly to help establish a strong root system. After the tree is established, it typically needs watering only during prolonged dry spells. Ensure the soil is well-draining to prevent root rot, as excessive moisture can be detrimental to its health. It's important to allow the soil to dry out between watering sessions to mimic its natural habitat, which can help reduce the risk of diseases affecting the plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Acacia baileyana thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least 6 hours of direct sun each day to grow robustly and produce its characteristic vibrant yellow flowers. It can tolerate light shade, especially in hotter climates, but optimal flowering and growth occur in open, sunny locations. In environments where the intensity of the sun is extremely high, it may benefit from some afternoon shade to protect it from scorching. Ensuring it has adequate sunlight also helps maintain healthy foliage and compact growth, reducing the likelihood of legginess and poor structural development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Acacia baileyana is usually done to maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. The best time to prune is immediately after flowering, which typically occurs in late winter to early spring. Remove any dead, diseased, or crossing branches to improve air circulation and light penetration. Additionally, regular pruning can help control its size and shape, especially if space is limited. Don't prune too harshly; otherwise, you may weaken the plant. Keeping the tree open by removing the inner branches can also prevent it from becoming overly dense, which reduces pest and disease issues."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Cootamundra wattle","description":"Acacia baileyana or Cootamundra wattle is a shrub or tree in the genus Acacia. The scientific name of the species honours the botanist Frederick Manson Bailey. It is indigenous to a small area of southern New South Wales in Australia, but it has been widely planted in other Australian states and territories. In many areas of Victoria, it has become naturalised and is regarded as a weed, outcompeting indigenous Victorian species.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Gray-green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Australia"],"other_name":["Cootamundra wattle"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Mite","Beetle"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Acacia baileyana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Ensure the soil is well-drained to prevent waterlogging, as excess moisture can cause root rot. Once mature, the tree typically requires watering only during prolonged droughts, as it will generally thrive on natural rainfall."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"The bur oak, Quercus macrocarpa, thrives in full sun conditions, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight daily. The best time for pruning is during the dormant season, typically in late winter or early spring, before new growth begins. Consider cutting back any crossing branches and thinning out dense sections to improve air circulation, which helps prevent disease. Avoid topping the tree, as it can lead to structural weakness."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"bur oak","description":"Quercus macrocarpa, the bur oak, sometimes spelled burr oak, is a species of oak in the white oak section Quercus sect. Ensure that the soil has good drainage to prevent water from pooling around the plant's roots, which can be detrimental to its health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ilex aquifolium thrives in locations with full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 4-5 hours of direct sunlight per day to produce its iconic glossy, spiky leaves. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch. This adaptability to various light conditions makes it suitable for a range of garden positions. If growing indoors or in a shaded area, ensure it gets some indirect yet bright light to maintain its vigor and appearance. Be cautious about extremes, as too much shade can reduce leaf density and berry production."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ilex aquifolium is best done in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. Prune to maintain the desired shape and size, encouraging bushier growth by cutting back long stems to a bud. Remove any dead, diseased, or damaged branches to improve overall plant health. When pruning, always use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts, and try to maintain the natural shape of the plant. Regular pruning helps manage its size and boosts health by allowing better air circulation and light penetration."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"European holly","description":"Ilex aquifolium (holly, common holly, English holly, European holly, or occasionally Christmas holly), is a species of holly native to western and southern Europe, northwest Africa, and southwest Asia. Regular removal of spent inflorescences and faded foliage not only keeps the plant tidy but also prevents potential diseases. Avoid cutting back too much foliage at once, as this could shock the plant. Maintain regular pruning to control its spread, as it can become invasive."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"tall flatsedge","description":"Cyperus eragrostis is a species of sedge known by several common names, including tall flatsedge, nutgrass, tall nutgrass, umbrella sedge, chufa, Earth almond, zula nuts, edible galingale and pale galingale.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["tall flatsedge"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Cyperus eragrostis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11294,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lupinus formosus, commonly known as summer lupine, prefers well-draining soil and should be watered thoroughly but infrequently. In gardens, particularly during dry periods or when heat increases evaporation, a deep watering once or twice a week is typically sufficient. Be sure to monitor for signs of drought stress, such as wilting leaves, and adjust your watering schedule accordingly. During the dormant winter months, reduce watering dramatically to account for the plant's lower metabolic needs."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lupinus formosus thrives best in full sunlight, which means it requires at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. In these conditions, the plant will produce vibrant, healthy blooms. While it can tolerate some light shade, too little light may result in leggy growth and reduced flowering. In particularly hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch. Position the plant in an area where it is exposed to the morning sun but protected from the harshest afternoon rays to balance light exposure and temperature stress."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lupinus formosus is generally minimal but beneficial for plant health and appearance. Deadheading—removing spent flowers—encourages continuous blooming and prevents the plant from putting energy into seed production. After the flowering season, cutting back the stems helps maintain a tidy appearance and encourages vigorous growth in the spring. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased foliage as needed to prevent pest infestations and promote air circulation. Always use sharp, sterilized pruning shears to avoid introducing pathogens to the plant. Pruning is best done in the early growing season and after flowering."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Summer Lupine","description":"Lupinus formosus, the summer lupine or western lupine, is a species of flowering plant in the legume family, Fabaceae. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10793,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Solanum tuberosum, commonly known as the potato, requires consistent moisture throughout the growing season. It's important to provide deep and regular watering to encourage the development of tubers. Generally, potatoes need about 1-2 inches of water per week, either through rainfall or supplemental irrigation. The soil should be kept moist but not waterlogged to prevent rot and disease. Inadequate watering can lead to small or misshaped tubers, so it's crucial to keep the soil consistently damp, especially during the critical growth periods of tuber development and maturation."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Potato plants, or Solanum tuberosum, thrive in full sunlight and require a minimum of 6-8 hours of direct sun per day. Adequate sunlight is crucial for photosynthesis, which supports healthy growth and tuber production. Plant potatoes in an area where they are not shaded by buildings, trees, or other structures. If sunlight is limited, consider growing early-maturing varieties, which can do slightly better in less-than-ideal light conditions. Ensuring your potatoes receive ample sunlight will result in more robust plants and an increased yield of tubers."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not typically necessary for Solanum tuberosum, as it is a crop grown for its tubers. However, you can remove any dead or diseased foliage to maintain plant health, and if the plant grows excessively tall or leggy, you can trim back the tops slightly. This can help improve air circulation and sunlight penetration, both of which are beneficial to the plant. Be sure not to prune the foliage too much, as the leaves are essential for photosynthesis, which supports tuber growth. Proper management of foliage can also support a healthy yield."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"potato","description":"The potato is a starchy, tuberous crop from the perennial nightshade Solanum tuberosum. The word \"potato\" may refer either to the plant itself or to the edible tuber. In the Andes, where the species is indigenous, some other closely related species are cultivated. Potatoes were introduced to Europe in the second half of the 16th century by the Spanish.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South America","Peru","Chile"],"other_name":["potato"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Mildew","Aphids","Colorado potato beetles","Nematodes","Wireworms"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Solanum tuberosum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11197,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Campanula barbata, also known as the bearded bellflower, prefers consistently moist but not waterlogged soil. Water the plant regularly, especially during dry periods, ensuring the soil remains damp to the touch. However, it's essential to avoid overwatering to prevent root rot. During the plant’s active growth and flowering periods in spring and summer, increase watering frequency, but always allow the top layer of soil to dry slightly between waterings. Reduce watering in the winter months when the plant is dormant, allowing the soil to retain just enough moisture to prevent complete drying out."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Campanula barbata thrives best in full sun to partial shade environments. For optimal growth, provide the plant with at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight daily. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can help protect the plant from intense sun that could scorch the foliage. However, ensure the plant receives adequate brightness to encourage strong growth and prolific blooming. If growing indoors, place the plant near a south or west-facing window where it can soak up sufficient sunlight, or use a grow light to supplement natural light if needed."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Campanula barbata involves removing spent flowers and dead or damaged foliage to encourage a tidy appearance and promote continued blooming. Deadhead the faded flowers regularly to prevent the plant from going to seed, thereby extending the flowering period. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to make precise cuts just above a leaf node or base of the stem. In late autumn, after the flowering season, cut back the plant to ground level to prepare it for the winter months. This also helps maintain the plant’s health and vigor for the following growing season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Bearded Bellflower","description":"Campanula barbata, common name Bearded Bellflower, is a species of perennial bellflower in the family Campanulaceae.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Bearded Bellflower"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Campanula barbata"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10898,"attracts":["Birds","Mammals"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Chinkapin Oak (Quercus muehlenbergii) prefers moderate watering, especially during its early growth stages. Once established, it becomes more drought-tolerant but still benefits from occasional watering during prolonged dry periods. Water deeply and ensure that the soil is well-draining to prevent waterlogging, which can harm the roots. As a general rule, provide water when the top 1-2 inches of soil are dry to the touch. Adjust the frequency of watering based on local climate conditions and seasonal rainfall patterns. Mulching around the base can help retain soil moisture and reduce the need for frequent watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"The Chinkapin Oak thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth. It can tolerate partial shade but performs best in bright conditions. When selecting a site for planting, choose a location that provides ample sunlight exposure throughout the day to support robust growth and health. Avoid overly shady spots that may lead to poor development and increased susceptibility to pests. Additionally, adequate sunlight aids in the production of acorns, a key characteristic of mature Chinkapin Oaks. Ensuring adequate sunlight helps this oak reach its full potential."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Quercus muehlenbergii is mainly done to maintain its shape and remove any dead or diseased branches. The best time to prune is during late winter or early spring when the tree is still dormant. Start by removing any damaged or crossing branches to improve air circulation and light penetration. Avoid heavy pruning, as Chinkapin Oaks can be sensitive to excessive cutting. Maintaining a natural shape is ideal, so selective thinning rather than canopy reduction is recommended. Regular inspection for any signs of disease can help keep the tree healthy. Ensure tools are clean to prevent disease spread."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"chinkapin oak","description":"Quercus muehlenbergii, the chinkapin oak (or chinquapin oak), is an oak in the white oak group (Quercus sect. Quercus). The species was often called Quercus acuminata in older literature. Quercus muehlenbergii, (its specific epithet often misspelt muhlenbergii) is native to eastern and central North America, ranging from Vermont west to Wisconsin and south to South Carolina, western Florida, New Mexico, and northeastern Mexico from Coahuila south to Hidalgo.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["chinkapin oak"],"pest_susceptibility":["Gypsy moth","Oak leaf miner"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Quercus muehlenbergii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Slightly acidic","Calcareous"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Lightly trimming back vigorous growth during the growing season can help maintain a more compact form and encourage a denser foliage."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"American holly","description":"Ilex opaca, the American holly, is a species of holly, native to the eastern and south-central United States, from coastal Massachusetts south to central Florida, and west to southeastern Missouri and eastern Texas.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Dark green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Eastern United States"],"other_name":["American holly"],"pest_susceptibility":["Leaf miners","Scale insects"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Ilex opaca"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Proper light exposure is crucial for vibrant blooms and healthy foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Erica carnea is relatively straightforward and is best done in early spring immediately after flowering. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to promote healthy growth. Avoid severe pruning, which can stress the plant. Light pruning helps in maintaining an attractive form and ensures prolific blooming in the next season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Spring Heath","description":"Erica carnea (winter heath, winter-flowering heather, spring heath, alpine heath; syn. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10899,"attracts":["Birds","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Quercus coccinea, commonly known as the Scarlet Oak, prefers well-drained soil and is drought-tolerant once established. It requires regular watering during its first few years to develop a deep root system. Water deeply, allowing the soil to dry out between watering sessions. Over-watering can lead to root rot, so ensure that the plant is not sitting in water. During dry periods, especially in summer, additional watering may be necessary. Mulching around the base can help conserve moisture and moderate soil temperature, which encourages healthy growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Scarlet Oaks thrive in full sun, needing at least six hours of direct sunlight each day to grow well. They tolerate light shade but will have denser foliage and more vibrant fall color in sunny locations. Choosing a planting spot that receives ample sunlight will promote strong growth and enhance the tree’s natural beauty. Additionally, sufficient sunlight exposure helps reduce moisture retention on leaves, which can limit fungal issues. In landscapes, these oaks are often admired for their hardiness and capacity to offer shade, making them suitable for wide, open areas."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Quercus coccinea is typically done to maintain shape and remove any dead or diseased branches. It is best to prune in late winter or early spring before new growth begins, as this minimizes stress to the tree. Focus on removing any branches that cross or rub together and thin the canopy if necessary to allow light and air to circulate. Avoid heavy pruning, as this oak generally retains a natural shape. Always use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts that heal quickly. Regular inspection can help catch issues early and keep the tree healthy."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"scarlet oak","description":"Quercus coccinea, the scarlet oak, is an oak in the red oak section Quercus sect. Lobatae. The scarlet oak can be mistaken for the pin oak, the black oak, or occasionally the red oak. On scarlet oak the sinuses between lobes are \"C\"-shaped in comparison to pin oak (Q. palustris), which has \"U\"-shaped sinuses and the acorns are half covered by a deep cap.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["scarlet oak"],"pest_susceptibility":["Leaf Spot","Oak Leaf Blister","Scale Insects"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Quercus coccinea"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11296,"attracts":["Pollinator insects"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Medicago sativa, commonly known as alfalfa, requires moderate watering. It is drought-tolerant once established but benefits from regular watering to maximize growth and yield. During its active growth period, aim to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Overwatering can lead to root rot, especially in poorly drained soils. It's crucial to allow the topsoil to dry out slightly between watering. During periods of dormancy, such as winter, watering can be significantly reduced. Always consider local weather conditions; if rainfall is abundant, you may not need to water as frequently."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Medicago sativa thrives in full sunlight and benefits from at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight per day. Being a sun-loving plant, alfalfa grows best in open, sunny locations, and insufficient sunlight can lead to poor growth and reduced yields. In areas with hot climates, although it tolerates heat, extreme prolonged exposure without adequate water might stress the plant. While it can manage in slightly shadier spots, optimal sunlight ensures better photosynthesis, leading to healthier plants and enhanced growth. Early morning sunlight helps with dew evaporation, reducing fungal risks."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Medicago sativa is generally not necessary in the traditional sense; however, it can be harvested multiple times a season to maintain vigor and encourage new growth. Regular cutting can help manage its height and promote a bushier appearance. It's typically harvested when reaching about 10% bloom, as cutting at this stage can balance quality with growth potential. During the growing season, you can cut it back every few weeks depending on its growth rate and your intended use. After the last harvest of the season, a final mow at a higher height can help protect it during winter."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Alfalfa","description":"Alfalfa /ælˈfælfə/, Medicago sativa also called lucerne, is a perennial flowering plant in the pea family Fabaceae cultivated as an important forage crop in many countries around the world. It is used for grazing, hay, and silage, as well as a green manure and cover crop. The name alfalfa is used in North America. The name lucerne is the more commonly used name in the United Kingdom, South Africa, Australia, and New Zealand. The plant superficially...","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Southwest Asia","Eastern Mediterranean"],"other_name":["Alfalfa"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Medicago sativa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12002,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Calochortus kennedyi, commonly known as the Desert Mariposa Lily, requires relatively low amounts of water, making it ideal for dry regions. During their growing season in early spring, water them sparingly but ensure that the soil is well-draining. Avoid overwatering, as this can lead to bulb rot. Once the blooming period ends in late spring or early summer, significantly reduce watering as the plant enters dormancy. Mimic natural desert conditions by keeping the soil dry in summer and fall, only reintroducing light watering in the winter or early spring when new growth is anticipated."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Calochortus kennedyi thrives in full sun, similar to its native desert habitat. It requires at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day to achieve optimal growth and flowering. If grown indoors or in regions with less natural sunlight, provide supplementary lighting to mimic full-sun conditions. The plant's tolerance for high light levels makes it suitable for rock gardens, open fields, or sun-drenched borders. However, if the sun is particularly intense or the temperatures extremely high, some afternoon shade can prevent excessive stress and potential wilting."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Calochortus kennedyi is minimal. After the flowering season, you may deadhead spent flowers to prevent seed production if self-seeding is not desired. Allow the foliage to die back naturally after the blooming period. This process ensures that the bulb stores enough energy for the next growth cycle. Once the foliage is completely brown and dry, you can gently remove it by cutting it close to the ground. Avoid cutting green leaves as they are crucial for photosynthesis and aiding the plant's growth cycle for the following year."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"desert mariposa lily","description":"Calochortus kennedyi is a North American species of flowering plant in the lily family known by the common name desert mariposa lily.","family":null,"flower_color":"Orange","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["desert mariposa lily"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Calochortus kennedyi"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11499,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Stanleya pinnata, or Prince's Plume, is drought-tolerant and has low watering needs. It grows well in well-drained soil and is adapted to dry climates. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it is crucial to allow the soil to dry out between waterings. During the growing season, water the plant every 2-3 weeks if no rainfall occurs, reducing to once a month in winter. Ensure the water is deeply soaked into the soil to encourage deep root growth, and always check the soil moisture to avoid excess water-retention. Adjust watering frequency based on the plant's environment and appearance."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Stanleya pinnata thrives in full sun to light shade, but for optimal growth and flowering, full sun is recommended. The plant is well-suited to hot, sunny conditions found in arid or semiarid environments. It can handle some partial shade, particularly in the hottest parts of the day, but too much shade can reduce blooming and make the plant leggy. Ensure the plant receives at least six hours of direct sunlight daily. If grown indoors or in areas with less natural sunlight, consider supplementing with a grow light to mimic its sunny natural habitat."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Stanleya pinnata is generally minimal. It's best to prune the plant after it blooms to remove any dead or spent flower stalks, promoting a tidy appearance and encouraging new growth. Use clean, sharp shears to avoid damaging the plant. If the plant becomes leggy or oversized, you can selectively prune back some of the oldest growth to shape the plant and improve air circulation. Always remove any damaged or diseased branches to prevent the spread of disease. Regular pruning can also help in preventing the plant from becoming too woody or sparse at the base."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Desert Prince's Plume","description":"Stanleya pinnata is a species of flowering plant in the mustard family known by the common name desert princesplume.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States","Canada","Mexico"],"other_name":["Desert Prince's Plume"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Stanleya pinnata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Removing foliage too early can prevent the bulbs from developing properly. If desired, you may remove the spent flowers and stems to keep the garden tidy, but be careful not to disturb the leaves during the energy storage phase."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Woodland crocus","description":"Crocus tommasinianus, the woodland crocus, early crocus, or Tommasini's crocus, often referred to as 'tommies', were named after the botanist Muzio G. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10496,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Sempervivum tectorum, commonly known as Houseleek, requires minimal watering as it's a drought-tolerant succulent. Water the plant sparingly, allowing the soil to dry out completely between watering sessions. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's crucial to monitor the soil moisture levels. In the growing season (spring and summer), watering once every two weeks should suffice. During the dormant period (fall and winter), reduce the frequency even further—watering once a month can be sufficient. Ensure that drainage is excellent to prevent water from pooling at the base of the plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sempervivum tectorum thrives in full sun, needing around six to eight hours of bright, direct sunlight each day. Providing adequate sunlight is essential for its health and vibrant coloration. When grown indoors, place these succulents near the brightest window, preferably south-facing. If natural light is insufficient, consider supplementing with a grow light to mimic the sunlight exposure it needs. Outdoors, choose a spot that receives plenty of sunlight throughout the day to mimic its native alpine environment. Insufficient light can lead to leggy growth and faded colors."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Sempervivum tectorum is minimal and mainly involves the removal of dead leaves and offsets, also known as chicks. Regularly inspect the plant for any brown or dying leaves and gently pull them away from the base to keep the plant healthy and to allow for new growth. As the plant produces offsets, they can be gently twisted or cut away from the parent plant for propagation or to control size. Pruning is best done during the growing season to promote vigorous growth and to maintain the plant's shape and health."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Houseleek","description":"Sempervivum tectorum (common houseleek) is a species of flowering plant in the family Crassulaceae, native to the mountains of southern Europe, cultivated in the whole of Europe for its appearance and a Roman tradition claiming that it protects buildings against lightning strikes.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Houseleek"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Offset Separation","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Sempervivum tectorum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Insufficient sunlight can lead to weak, leggy growth, while adequate sunlight helps maintain its healthy, robust form. During very hot periods, some partial afternoon shade can prevent sunburn, though this plant is highly resistant to heat and intense light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Cylindropuntia bigelovii is mainly for removing dead or diseased stems and controlling its shape. Use tongs or heavy gloves to handle the plant due to its spiky nature. Pruning can be done anytime you notice dead parts, but ideally during warmer months when the plant is actively growing. Cut the branches at their joints; new growth will emerge from these points. Be cautious of fallen spines and segments, as they can root where they land. Pruning encourages a healthy structure and stimulates new growth, ensuring the plant remains attractive and manageable."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Teddybear Cholla","description":"Cylindropuntia bigelovii, the teddy bear cholla, is a cholla cactus species native to Northwestern Mexico, and to the United States in California, Arizona, and Nevada.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Southwestern United States","Northwestern Mexico"],"other_name":["Teddybear Cholla"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Cylindropuntia bigelovii"],"soil":["Sandy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In cultivation, maintaining a moderate level of moisture in the substrate is crucial. Ensure that the habitat is kept damp but not waterlogged to mimic its natural forest floor environment. Avoid letting the substrate dry out completely, as consistent moisture is necessary for optimal growth. Regularly mist the growing area to maintain humidity, but be careful not to oversaturate, as excess water can lead to fungal rot or other growth issues."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Clavaria fragilis thrives in shaded areas typically found on forest floors, thus it prefers indirect sunlight or dappled light conditions. When cultivating this fungus, try to replicate its natural habitat by providing it with low to moderate light levels. Direct sunlight can be harmful, potentially drying out the substrate and the mycelial network. Indoor cultivation should focus on LED grow lights that simulate the dappled forest light conditions, ensuring the growing environment is adequately illuminated without excessive exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Unlike traditional garden plants, Clavaria fragilis does not require pruning. As a fungus, it will naturally decompose back into the environment once its fruiting body matures and completes its reproductive cycle. Any physical removal should only be done to harvest for study or aesthetic management in controlled environments. This process does not harm the organism as the main growing body, the mycelium, remains unharmed in the substrate."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Fairy Fingers","description":"Clavaria fragilis, commonly known as fairy fingers, white worm coral, or white spindles, is a species of fungus in the family Clavariaceae. It is synonymous with Clavaria vermicularis. The fungus is the type species of the genus Clavaria and is a typical member of the clavarioid or club fungi. It produces tubular, unbranched, white basidiocarps (fruit bodies) that typically grow in clusters. The fruit bodies can reach dimensions of 15 cm (5.9 in) tall by 0.5 cm (0.2 in) thick....","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America","Europe"],"other_name":["Fairy Fingers"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["January"],"scientific_name":["Clavaria fragilis"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
